resources.string: Coronaviruses (CoV) are a large family of viruses that cause illness ranging from the common cold to more severe diseases. Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus.\n It was first found in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The name ‘corona’ came from the many crown-like spikes on the surface of the virus.\n Symptoms of Covid-19 usually appear after 2 - 14days after receiving the virus.

Delta - B.1.617.2
 • First identified: India
 • Spread: Much faster than other variants
 • Severe illness and death: May cause more severe cases than the other variants
 • Treatments: Certain monoclonal antibody treatments are less effective against this variant.


Alpha - B.1.1.7
 • First identified: UK
 • Severity: the mortality hazard ratio associated with infection with the variant compared with infection with previously circulating variants was 1.64 in patients in the community.


Beta - B.1.351
 • First identified: South Africa
 • Severity: The variant was associated with in-hospital mortality that was 20% higher in the second wave in South Africa than in the first wave.


Gamma - P.1
 • First identified: Brazil
 • Severity: No strong evidence for an enhanced lethality
 • Spread: 2.5times more contagious than original coronavirus

• The virus travels in respiratory droplets when an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks, sings or breathes near you (within six feet).
 • When the virus travels in small respiratory droplets that linger in the air for minutes to hours from an infected person who is more than six feet away or has since left the space. This method of spread is more likely to occur in enclosed spaces with poor ventilation.
 • From close contact (touching, shaking hands) with an infected person.
 • By touching eyes, mouth, nose without washing hands after having contact with the virus.

• Wear a mask in public area.
 • Choose open, well-ventilated spaces over closed ones. Open a window if indoors.
 • Stay home if you feel unwell.
 • Sanitize or wash hands frequently.
 • Maintain at least 1 metre of distance.
 • Get vaccinated.

mRNA
 • How it reacts: mRNA sequence that enters individual cell and produce the specific virus protein
 • Function: mRNA molecule stimulate the immune system to recognise the virus protein
 • Advantages: Simple, Quick to produce, Does not require living component, Triggers an adaptive response
 • Challenges: Require extremely cold storage conditions
 • Examples: Moderna, Pfizer/BioNTech


Viral Vector
 • How it reacts: Transports the antigen genetic code. Human cells reproduce targeted protein
 • Function: Stimulates the immune system by introducing a safe viral vector into the body
 • Advantages: Proven technology, Triggers an adaptive response
 • Challenges: Complex manufacturing process, Need to ensure the viral vector is safe to be used
 • Examples: AstraZeneca, Sputnik V


Inactive Virus
 • How it reacts: Virus that has been killed through high heat/radiation
 • Function: Virus that has been killed entering the human body to trigger the immune system
 • Advantages: Proven technology, Suitable for those with weak immune system, Easy to produce
 • Challenges: High manufacturing cost
 • Examples: Sinovac V
